column1: At the man's heels trotted a dog
column4: gray-coated and without any visible or temperamental difference from its brother
column5: the wild wolf. The animal was depressed by the tremendous cold. It knew that it was no time for travelling. Its instinct told it a truer tale than was told to the man by the man's judgment. In reality
column6: it was not merely colder than fifty below zero; it was colder than sixty below
column7: than seventy below. It was seventy-five below zero. Since the freezing-point is thirty-two above zero
column8: it meant that one hundred and seven degrees of frost obtained. The dog did not know anything about thermometers. Possibly in its brain there was no sharp consciousness of a condition of very cold such as was in the man's brain. But the brute had its instinct. It experienced a vague but menacing apprehension that subdued it and made it slink along at the man's heels
column9: and that made it question eagerly every unwanted movement of the man as if expecting him to go into camp or to seek shelter somewhere and build a fire.
